claim: A 3-year-old boy who has no known past medical or family history is brought by his parents to his pediatrician for new symptoms. Specifically, his parents state that he has suffered from a fever associated with diarrhea and conjunctivitis over the past week or so. His parents note that he has never had an episode of diarrhea like this previously, but that several other children at his daycare had been ill recently. The blood pressure is 112/70 mm Hg, heart rate is 94/min, respiratory rate is 14/min, and temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F). The physical exam is significant for preauricular adenopathy. Which of the following interventions would have been most effective to prevent this condition? : Better hand-washing practices

supporting.text: Better hand-washing practices reduce the transmission of infectious agents, which are a common cause of diarrhea and conjunctivitis in daycare settings.

attacks.text: Better hand-washing practices reduce the transmission of infectious agents, which are a common cause of diarrhea and conjunctivitis in daycare settings.
Hand-washing alone may not be sufficient if the infectious agent is airborne or spread through surfaces that are not routinely cleaned.
Children at this age may not comply with hand-washing protocols effectively, limiting the intervention's impact.
Supervised hand-washing sessions and the use of hand sanitizers can improve compliance among young children.
Regular disinfection of high-touch surfaces in daycare settings can complement hand-washing to reduce transmission.
Even with supervision, young children may not wash their hands thoroughly enough to eliminate all pathogens.

supporting.text: The symptoms and preauricular adenopathy suggest a viral etiology, such as adenovirus, which is highly contagious and preventable through improved hygiene.

attacks.text: The symptoms and preauricular adenopathy suggest a viral etiology, such as adenovirus, which is highly contagious and preventable through improved hygiene.
